intro: Hemisantiria rugosa, commonly known as the rough-hairied mallow, is a flowering plant native to tropical regions of South America. It belongs to the Malvaceae family, which includes cotton and hibiscus, and is characterized by its hairy stems and broad, heart-shaped leaves. The plant produces showy, pink to purple flowers that bloom in clusters, attracting pollinators such as bees and butterflies. Its fibrous roots and woody stems make it a hardy species adapted to various soil types and environmental conditions.
